channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: VA research brought CT scans and pacemakers into the world. Now it's at risk of cuts
item.description: Researchers at the Department of Veterans Affairs warn that crucial medical research is in jeopardy unless the Trump administration reverses course on cuts.

item.title: Baked, fried or fileted: Fish dishes can link us to our histories
item.description: The food we grow up with says a lot about our heritage and community. Researchers are on a mission to connect people to local fishers — and introduce more Americans to a more diverse array of seafood.

item.title: Vietnam War: some families of Vietnamese MIAs are calling on the U.S. to help
item.description: Fifty years after the end of the war, Hanoi says nearly 200,000 Vietnamese soldiers are still missing. Some of their families are now calling on the U.S. to help find them.

item.title: Chicken thighs pass chicken breasts in price and popularity
item.description: For decades in the U.S., chicken breasts were pricier and more popular than chicken thighs. But that seems to be changing.

item.title: New survey reveals changing attitudes about Alzheimer's disease
item.description: A new survey from the Alzheimer's Association finds that people want to know if they are in the early stages of the disease, and are open to drug treatment.

item.title: A 20-year-old Portland tradition serves coffee and doughnuts to bikers on bridges
item.description: On the last Friday of each month in Portland, Ore., volunteers pass out breakfast items to bike commuters in an event called "Breakfast on the Bridges."

item.title: Life Kit has tips on raising kids bilingually and the benefits it can provide
item.description: There are a lot of benefits to raising a child speaking two or more languages. NPR's Life Kit explains that raising a kid in a multilingual household isn't a burden — it's a gift.

item.title: Mark Carney won Canada's election after a campaign dominated by Trump
item.description: Canadians have chosen Mark Carney as prime minister, in what is seen as one of the most remarkable elections in decades. Much of the race has been centered on which candidate can best handle Trump.

item.title: Gaza's hungry and malnourished kids suffer under Israeli blockade
item.description: Israel has blocked vital supplies from entering Gaza for two months now. Children in Gaza are malnourished and dying as the UN runs out of food.

item.title: A world soccer tournament made for grandmothers
item.description: A world soccer tournament for 'grannies' has wrapped up. The annual event allows women from all over the world to show off and be appreciated for their athleticism.
